Recommended for muscle growth: 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps. 

For strength development: 4-5 sets of 6-8 reps. 

Rest Time:

Warm-up How to Do Caloric Burn (10 minutes) Benefits Duration per Day Timing
Running / Jogging Dynamic stretches (leg swings, arm circles) and light jogging for 5-10 minutes
 Find a comfortable pace, use proper running shoes, and maintain good form
 Approximately 100-120 calorie
 Improved cardiovascular health, weight management, enhanced mood
 Start with 20-30 minutes and progress
 Morning or evening, based on personal preference


Cycling Start with light cycling or dynamic leg stretches
 Adjust the bike for proper fit, maintain a steady pace, and use proper cycling technique
 Approximately 70-80 calories
 Low-impact cardiovascular exercise, leg strength, and stamina
 Aim for 30 minutes to an hour for a moderate workout
 Morning or evening, depending on preference and schedule


Swimming Swim at a slow pace and include arm and leg stretches
 Learn proper swimming techniques, start with basic strokes, and gradually increase intensity
 Approximately 80-100 calories
 Full-body workout, improved lung capacity, low-impact exercise
 Start with 20-30 minutes and progress
 Morning or evening, depending on availability


Jump Rope Jump at a slow pace and include ankle and wrist circles
 Use a proper-sized rope, maintain good posture, and start with basic jumps
 Approximately 100-120 calories
 Cardiovascular fitness, coordination, and agility
 Start with 10-15 minutes and increase gradually
 Morning or evening, depending on preference


High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) Include dynamic stretches and light aerobic activity
 Alternate between short bursts of intense exercise and rest periods
 Approximately 100-150 calories
 Efficient calorie burning, improved cardiovascular fitness, and time-effective
 15-30 minutes, including intervals
 Morning or evening, depending on preference


Rowing Perform light rowing or dynamic stretches
 Learn proper rowing technique, maintain good posture, and use a controlled motion
 Approximately 70-90 calories
 Full-body workout, low-impact, and improves cardiovascular health
 Start with 15-20 minutes and progress
 Morning or evening, depending on preference


Elliptical Trainer Begin with light elliptical activity and include dynamic stretches
 Use proper form, adjust resistance as needed, and maintain a steady pace
 Approximately 80-100 calories
 Low-impact cardiovascular exercise, works multiple muscle groups
 Aim for 30 minutes to an hour
 Morning or evening, based on preference


Dancing Dance at a slow pace, incorporating various dance moves
 Choose dance styles you enjoy, follow instructional videos if needed
 Approximately 60-90 calories (varies with intensity)
 Cardiovascular fitness, improved coordination, and mood enhancement
 Start with 20-30 minutes and increase
 Evening is popular, but any time based on personal preference


Boxing Shadow> boxing, light punches, and dynamic stretches
 Learn basic boxing stance, punches, and footwork
 Approximately 100-120 calories
 Cardiovascular workout, stress relief, and improved agility
 Start with 15-30 minutes and progress
 Morning or evening, based on preference


Hiking Begin with a brisk walk and light stretches
 Choose varied terrains, wear appropriate footwear, and pace yourself
 Approximately 70-90 calories
 Cardiovascular exercise, improved mood, and connection with nature
 Start with 30 minutes to an hour
 Morning or daytime for safety and enjoyment



Nurtitions
Carbohydrates Proteins Fats Calories Vitamins Minerals Water Dietary Fiber Antioxidants Probiotics Prebiotics Essential Fatty Acids
What it does : How is processed in our body: How much can we take per day: How to take:
Whats is Carbohydrates ? Carbohydrates are organic compounds consisting of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. They are classified into simple carbohydrates (sugars) and complex carbohydrates (starches and fiber) Carbohydrates serve as the primary and preferred source of energy for the body. Glucose, the product of carbohydrate breakdown, is essential for fueling cellular processes, especially in the brain and muscles. During digestion, complex carbohydrates are broken down into simple sugars (glucose, fructose, and galactose), which are then absorbed into the bloodstream. Insulin, a hormone produced by the pancreas, helps cells take up glucose for energy or storage in the liver and muscles. The Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend that 45-65% of daily caloric intake should come from carbohydrates. For adults, the recommended daily intake is around 130 grams, but individual needs vary based on factors such as age, gender, activity level, and overall health. Prioritize whole, unprocessed carbohydrates from sources like fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes. Limit the intake of added sugars from processed foods and beverages




What is Protein? Proteins are complex macromolecules composed of amino acids, which are crucial for building and repairing tissues in the body. Proteins play essential roles in immune function, enzyme production, and the structure of muscles, organs, and skin. They also serve as a source of energy when needed. During digestion, proteins are broken down into individual amino acids, which are then absorbed into the bloodstream and used for various physiological functions, including the synthesis of new proteins. The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for protein is approximately 0.8 grams per kilogram of body weight for adults. However, individual protein needs can vary based on factors such as age, activity level, and health status. Include a variety of protein sources in your diet, such as lean meats, poultry, fish, eggs, dairy products, legumes, and plant-based options like tofu and tempeh



.
What is Fat? Fats are organic molecules that are a concentrated source of energy, consisting of fatty acids and glycerol. Fats are essential for energy storage, hormone production, cell structure, and the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K). They also provide insulation and protection for organs. Dietary fats are broken down into fatty acids and glycerol during digestion. These components are then absorbed into the bloodstream and used for energy or stored in adipose tissue. The Dietary Guidelines recommend that 20-35% of daily caloric intake should come from fats. Its important to limit saturated and trans fats while prioritizing sources of monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats. Choose healthy fat sources, including avocados, nuts, seeds, olive oil, and fatty fish. Limit the consumption of processed and fried foods high in unhealthy fats.




What are Vitamins? Vitamins are organic compounds that play crucial roles in various physiological functions. They are divided into water-soluble (e.g., vitamin C, B-complex) and fat-soluble (e.g., vitamin A, D, E, K) categories. Types of Vitamins:
Use of Vitamin A Essential for vision, immune function, skin health, and cell differentiation.
Use of Vitamin B-Complex Supports energy metabolism, red blood cell formation, DNA synthesis, and nerve function.
Use of Vitamin C Acts as an antioxidant, supports immune function, and is crucial for collagen synthesis.
Use of Vitamin D Facilitates calcium absorption for bone health and supports immune function.
Use of Vitamin E Acts as an antioxidant, protects cell membranes, and supports immune function.
Use of Vitamin K Essential for blood clotting, bone metabolism, and heart health.
What Vitamins Does? Each vitamin has specific functions. For instance, vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis and supports the immune system, while vitamin D is crucial for calcium absorption and bone health.
How Vitamins are Processed? Vitamins are absorbed during digestion and participate in a range of biochemical reactions. Some act as coenzymes, facilitating enzymatic processes, while others contribute to structural integrity.
How Much Vitamins Can We Take Per Day? Recommended daily allowances (RDAs) vary for each vitamin. Adequate intake depends on factors such as age, gender, and health status. Consuming a diverse and balanced diet typically provides sufficient vitamins. How to Take Vitamins? Obtain vitamins from a variety of food sources, including fruits, vegetables, dairy products, lean meats, and fortified foods. In some cases, supplements may be recommended, especially for individuals with specific deficiencies.




What is Minerals? Minerals are inorganic elements essential for various bodily functions. They are classified as macrominerals (required in larger amounts) and trace minerals (needed in smaller amounts) Minerals have diverse roles; for example, calcium is critical for bone health, iron is necessary for oxygen transport in the blood, potassium regulates nerve and muscle function, and zinc supports immune function. Minerals are absorbed during digestion and participate in physiological processes, acting as cofactors for enzymes and contributing to structural components. Recommended daily allowances (RDAs) or adequate intakes (AIs) vary for each mineral. Individual needs depend on factors like age, gender, and health status. Consume a variety of foods rich in minerals, such as dairy products, leafy greens, nuts, seeds, legumes, and lean meats. In some cases, supplements may be recommended under the guidance of a healthcare professional.




What is Water? Water is a vital, tasteless, and odorless substance that is fundamental for life. 
 Water is essential for maintaining bodily functions, including temperature regulation, digestion, nutrient transport, and elimination of waste products. Water is absorbed through the digestive system and circulates in the bloodstream, facilitating various metabolic processes. It is excreted through urine, sweat, and respiration. Adequate daily intake varies, influenced by factors such as climate, physical activity, and individual health. A general guideline is to drink about 8 cups (64 ounces) or more per day. Consume water from various sources, including beverages and water-rich foods. Thirst is a natural indicator of hydration needs. Individual requirements may vary, so adjust intake based on factors like climate and activity level.




What is Dietary Fiber? Dietary fiber consists of non-digestible carbohydrates found in plant foods. Fiber promotes digestive health, helps prevent constipation, and may contribute to weight management by promoting a feeling of fullness. Fiber remains largely intact during digestion, adding bulk to the stool and promoting regular bowel movements. Some types of fiber can also be fermented by gut bacteria. Recommended daily intake varies, but a general guideline is around 25 grams for adult women and 38 grams for adult men. Include a variety of fiber-rich foods in your diet, such as whole grains, fruits, vegetables, legumes, and nuts. Gradually increase fiber intake to avoid digestive discomfort.




What are Antioxidants? Antioxidants are compounds that help neutralize free radicals, reducing oxidative stress and inflammation in the body. By preventing or repairing cell damage caused by free radicals, antioxidants contribute to overall health and may reduce the risk of chronic diseases. Antioxidants are obtained from various foods and supplements. They work by donating electrons to stabilize free radicals, thereby reducing cellular damage. There is no specific daily recommendation for antioxidants, but a varied and colorful diet rich in fruits and vegetables provides a broad spectrum of these compounds. Consume a diverse array of colorful fruits and vegetables, as well as nuts, seeds, and whole grains. Supplements may be considered in certain cases, but a balanced diet is generally the preferred source.




What are Probiotics? Probiotics are live microorganisms that confer health benefits, particularly to the digestive system. Probiotics help maintain a healthy balance of gut bacteria, supporting digestion and overall gut health. They may also have immune-modulating effects. Probiotics, when consumed, reach the gut and interact with the existing microbial community, influencing the balance of beneficial bacteria. There is no specific daily requirement for probiotics, but regular consumption of probiotic-rich foods can contribute to gut health. Include fermented foods such as yogurt, kefir, sauerkraut, and kimchi in your diet. Probiotic supplements may be considered, especially after antibiotic use or for individuals with specific digestive issues.




What are Prebiotics? Prebiotics are non-digestible fibers that promote the growth of beneficial gut bacteria. By serving as food for probiotics, prebiotics support the growth and activity of beneficial bacteria in the gut. Prebiotics pass undigested through the upper gastrointestinal tract and reach the colon, where they are fermented by gut bacteria. There is no specific daily requirement for prebiotics, but including a variety of prebiotic-rich foods can contribute to gut health. Consume foods rich in prebiotics, such as garlic, onions, leeks, bananas, whole grains, and certain vegetables. A diverse and fiber-rich diet supports both prebiotic and probiotic functions.




What are Essential Fatty Acids? Essential fatty acids include omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, which the body cannot produce and must be obtained from the diet. Omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids are critical for brain function, cardiovascular health, and reducing inflammation in the body. These fatty acids are incorporated into cell membranes and serve as precursors for the production of important signaling molecules. While there is no specific daily requirement, a balanced intake of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids is essential. The recommended ratio is generally 1:4 (omega-3 to omega-6). Include fatty fish (such as salmon and mackerel), flaxseeds, chia seeds, walnuts, and certain oils (like flaxseed oil and walnut oil) in your diet. Aim for a balanced intake of omega-3 and omega-6 sources.




What are Calories? Calories are a unit of measurement for the energy content of food. They represent the amount of energy released when the body breaks down and processes the nutrients in food. Calories provide the energy necessary for various bodily functions, including metabolism, physical activity, and the maintenance of basic physiological processes. During digestion, carbohydrates, proteins, and fats are broken down to release energy, measured in calories. The body utilizes this energy for immediate needs or stores it for future use. The recommended daily caloric intake varies based on factors such as age, gender, activity level, and health goals. Its essential to balance calorie intake with energy expenditure for overall well-being. Make informed food choices to meet your caloric needs while prioritizing nutrient-dense foods for optimal health. Pay attention to portion sizes and be mindful of overall energy balance.
